Apps.subtitle: A short description of Blockly.
Apps.blocklyMessage: The project name.  If readers of your language would know approximately how to pronounce 'Blockly', leave unchanged.  Otherwise, include a transliteration in parentheses, such as the Russian: 'Blockly (Блoкли)'.
Apps.projectMessage: The project name. 'CS' is an abbreviation for Computer Science. 'First' refers to the project's goal of introducing students to programming as early as possible in their life.
Apps.codeTooltip: tooltip (pop-up help) for button; pressing the button causes a program in the JavaScript computer language to be displayed, based on the program created by the user.
Apps.linkTooltip: tooltip - Clicking on this button will cause the current program to be saved and for a URL to be shown to later retrieve it.
Apps.runTooltip: tooltip - Pressing this button runs the computer program the user has written.
Apps.runProgram: button label - Pressing the button runs the computer program the user has written.
Apps.resetProgram: button label - Pressing the button causes the output of the program to be erased but does not delete the user's program).
Apps.dialogOk:
Label on button for user to press when done reading help information.
{{Identical|OK}}
Apps.dialogCancel:
Label on button for user to press when not wanting to proceed.
{{Identical|Cancel}}
Apps.help:
The label on a button the user can press for help.
{{Identical|Help}}
Apps.catText: category - Blocks related to [https://code.google.com/p/blockly/wiki/Text text processing].
Apps.catProcedures: category - Blocks related to [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Subroutine defining or using procedures/functions].
Apps.httpRequestError: alert - The URL is invalid or a server error occurred.  This message will be followed by technical information useful to engineers trying to understand the problem.
Apps.linkAlert:
alert - After the user has pressed a button to save his/her program, this provides the URL (%1) to retrieve the program.  The characters '

' indicate that a blank line will be displayed before the URL (in English).  Leave those in unless you move %1 to the beginning or middle of the text, in which case you should use your judgment about where blank lines would be most useful.
Apps.hashError: alert - A request to retrieve a stored program does not have a valid URL. %1 is the invalid portion of the URL.
Apps.xmlError: alert - There was a problem loading a file previously saved by the user.  The most likely reason for the problem is that it was created with an earlier, incompatible version of Blockly.  This message will be followed by technical information useful to engineers trying to understand the problem.
Apps.hintTitle: title - this indicates to the user that what follows are ways to improve and/or fix their code.
Apps.emptyBlocksErrorMsg: alert - This error message is displayed when the user has added blocks with nothing nested inside them (e.g. repeat or if blocks).
Apps.tooFewBlocksMsg: alert - The user has not completed the level, is using all of the necessary types of blocks, but needs more of these types of blocks to complete the level.
Apps.tooManyBlocksMsg: alert - This is displayed when the user has used more blocks than is necessary.
Apps.nextLevel: alert - This is displayed when the user solves the level, inviting them to precede to the next level of difficulty.
Apps.finalLevelMsg: alert - This is displayed when the user solves the most difficult level.
Apps.listVariable: variable name - Default [https://code.google.com/p/blockly/wiki/Variables variable] representing a [https://code.google.com/p/blockly/wiki/Lists list].  This should be a single word, preferably short.
Apps.textVariable: variable name - Default [https://code.google.com/p/blockly/wiki/Variables variable] representing a [https://code.google.com/p/blockly/wiki/Text piece of text].  This should be a single word, preferably short.
Bird.hungry: block text - Experiencing a desire or need for food.
Bird.heading: block text - the compass direction toward which a traveler or vehicle is or should be moving; course.
Bird.doIf: Conditional statement, which evaluates to true or false.
Bird.doCode: block text - Imperative or infinitive of a verb preceding one or more commands to a person.  This is part of [https://code.google.com/p/blockly/wiki/Loops#repeat repeat] and [https://code.google.com/p/blockly/wiki/IfElse#If_blocks if] blocks.
Bird.elseCode: block text - Conjunction meaning 'otherwise', introducing commands to be performed if a previous condition was not true, as in 'if x>3, do this, else do that'.  See [https://code.google.com/p/blockly/wiki/IfElse#If-Else_blocks].
Bird.hungryTooltip: tooltip - 'hungry' means the bird has not gotten its food.
Bird.headingTooltip: tooltip - Move in the direction of the given angle, where 0 means going horizontally to the right, and 90 straight up and 270 straight down.
Bird.positionTooltip: tooltip - (x, y) marks the coordinate of bird, (0, 0) is the bottom left corner and (100, 100) top right.
Bird.nextLevel: alert - This is displayed when the user solves the level, inviting them to precede to the next level of difficulty.  %1 is an integer greater than 1.
Bird.finalLevel: alert - This is displayed when the user solves the most difficult level.
Bird.bird: title - Specifies that this is Blockly's '''Bird''' tutorial.
Bird.runTooltip: tooltip - Pressing this button runs the computer program the user has written to move the player through the level.
Bird.resetTooltip: tooltip - Pressing this button restores the player to the start position and enables the user's program to be run again.
Maze.moveForward: verb - imperative or infinitive for a person moving (walking) in the direction he/she is facing.
Maze.turnLeft: verb - imperative or infinitive for a person turning his head and body one quarter rotation counter-clockwise.  Prefer a translation that has text in common with the translation of 'turn right'.  See [[Translating:Blockly#Drop-Down_Menus]].
Maze.turnRight: verb - imperative or infinitive for a person turning his head and body one quarter rotation clockwise. Prefer a translation that has text in common with the translation of 'turn left'.  See [[Translating:Blockly#Drop-Down_Menus]].
Maze.doCode: verb - imperative or infinitive preceding one or more commands to a person.
Maze.elseCode: conjunction - 'otherwise', introducing commands to be performed if a previous condition was not true, as in 'if x>3, do this, else do that'.
Maze.pathAhead: condensed form of 'if there is a path ahead', as in: 'if path ahead, go forward'.
Maze.pathLeft: condensed form of 'if there is a path to the left', as in: 'if path to the left, turn left'.
Maze.pathRight: condensed form of 'if there is a path to the right', as in: 'if path to the right, turn right'.
Maze.repeatUntil: verb - imperative or infinitive to repeat the following commands.  The phrase is followed by the symbol denoting the end of the maze.
Maze.moveForwardTooltip: tooltip (pop-up help) - Pegman is the humanoid icon used in Google Maps. See picture at http://goo.gl/9I64i (http://maps.google.com/intl/en/help/maps/streetview/learn/pegman.html). The term 'space' refers to a single square within a maze.
Maze.q3wrong: tracking is suggesting to the user that they should follow each instruction and follow how that will affect the movement. A 'program' is a set of instructions that tell the computer what to do next.
Maze.q3right: Congratulating the user on correctly answering the question.
Maze.q5wrong: Tracking is suggesting to the user that they should follow each instruction and follow how that will affect the movement. A 'program' is a set of instructions that tell the computer what to do next.
Maze.q5right: Congratulating the user on correctly answering the question.
Maze.q9wrong: tracking is suggesting to the user that they should follow each instruction and follow how that will affect the movement. A 'program' is a set of instructions that tell the computer what to do next.
Maze.q9right: Congratulating the user on correctly answering the question.
Maze.turnTooltip: tooltip (pop-up help) - Pegman is the humanoid icon used in Google Maps. See picture at http://goo.gl/9I64i (http://maps.google.com/intl/en/help/maps/streetview/learn/pegman.html). The term 'space' refers to a single square within a maze.
Maze.ifTooltip: tooltip (pop-up help) - 'path' refers to a path through a maze.
Maze.ifelseTooltip: tooltip (pop-up help) - 'path' refers to a path through a maze.
Maze.whileTooltip: tooltip (pop-up help) - Repeat the enclosed commands until the maze has been successfully completed (the end point reached).
Maze.capacity0: warning - No more blocks may be added until some are removed.  Do not alter the portions between pointy brackets (< and >), although you may move them within the phrase and replace 0 with one or more words.
Maze.capacity1: warning - Only one more block may be added.  Do not alter the portions between pointy brackets (< and >), although you may move them within the phrase and replace 1 with one or more words.
Maze.capacity2: warning - Only %1 more blocks may be used, where %1 is an integer greater than 1.  Do not alter the portions between pointy brackets (< and >), although you may move them within the phrase.
Maze.nextLevel: alert - This is displayed when the user solves the maze, inviting them to precede to the next level of difficulty.
Maze.finalLevel: alert - This is displayed when the user solves the most difficult level.
Maze.oneTopBlock: alert - This is displayed if a user attempts to run a program composed of multiple stacks of blocks, letting them know they need to create a single stack.
Maze.numBlocksNeeded: alert - This is displayed when the user has used more blocks than is necessary.
Maze.maze: brief title - Specifies that this is Blockly's '''Maze''' tutorial.
Maze.hintTitle: title - this indicates to the user that what follows are ways to improve and/or fix their code.
Maze.missingBlocksErrorMsg: alert- This error message is displayed when there are blocks missing from the user's program. This message is used to indicate that there are blocks displayed below that they should use. The blocks are generated by the application.
Maze.levelIncompleteError: alert - This message is is displayed to the user when they are using all of the correct types of blocks but perhaps not enough or in the correct order.
Maze.reinfMsg1: instructions - introduction to the Maze tutorial.
Maze.reinfMsg3: instructions - program' refers to a series of instructions that tell the computer what to do next.
Maze.reinfMsg2: instructions - 'block' refers to a child's stackable toys. A 'repeat' block is used to repeat blocks over and over. The red marker is the goal to be reached in the maze.
Maze.reinfMsg4: instructions - An example of an 'if' block is if there is a path to the left, turn left.
Maze.reinfMsg5: instructions - An example of an 'if' block is if there is a path to the left, turn left. A 'repeat' block is used to repeat blocks over and over. 'program' refers to a series of instructions that tell the computer what to do next.
Maze.reinfMsg6: instructions - A 'repeat' block is used to repeat blocks over and over.
Maze.reinfMsg8: instructions - An example of an 'if-else' block is if there is a path ahead move forward, else turn left.
Maze.reinfMsg9: instructions - 'block' refers to a child's stackable toys. A 'repeat' block is used to repeat blocks over and over. The red marker is the goal to be reached in the maze.
Maze.dirN: An abbreviation of the direction North
Maze.dirE: An abbreviation of the direction East
Maze.dirS: An abbreviation of the direction North
Maze.dirW: An abbreviation of the direction West
Maze.yes: Yes indicates that this option is correct.
Maze.no: No indicates that this option is incorrect.
Maze.tryAgain: button - Closes the dialog and stays on the current level
Maze.continue: button - Closes the dialog and continues to the next level
Maze.instructions1_m1: instructions - the word 'program' refers to a computer program, and the words for 'stack' and 'blocks' should be the same as for stacking children's blocks. Use the imperative verb form appropriate for speaking to a child, gender unspecified.  If no gender-neutral singular/familiar form exists but a gender-neutral plural/formal form exists, use that instead.
Maze.instructions2_m1: instructions - 'steps' refers to instructions in a computer program; 'path' refers to the path through a maze. See previous description for tense.
Maze.instructions3_m1: instructions - 'path' refers to a path through a maze, and 'block' refers to a child's building block.
Maze.instructions4_m1: instructions - the goal is reaching the end point in a maze; 'block' refers to a child's building block.
Maze.instructions5_m1: instructions - 'turn left' refers to rotating in place a quarter circle counter-clockwise. An example of an 'if' block is: 'if there is a path to the left, turn left'.
Maze.instructions6_m1: instructions - an example of an 'if' block is: 'if there is a path to the left, turn left'.
Maze.instructions7_m1: instructions - 'blocks' refers to a child's building blocks
Maze.instructions8_m1: instructions - an example of an 'if' block is: 'if there is a path to the left, turn left'.
Maze.instructions9_m1: instructions - 'block' refers to a child's building block.
Maze.instructions10_m1: instructions - an example of an 'if-else' block is: 'if there is a path to the left, turn left, else or otherwise turn right'.
Maze.instructions1_m2: instructions - the word 'program' refers to a computer program, and the words for 'stack' and 'blocks' should be the same as for stacking children's blocks. Use the imperative verb form appropriate for speaking to a child, gender unspecified.  If no gender-neutral singular/familiar form exists but a gender-neutral plural/formal form exists, use that instead.
Maze.instructions2_m2: instructions - the word 'program' refers to a computer program, and the words for 'stack' and 'blocks' should be the same as for stacking children's blocks. Use the imperative verb form appropriate for speaking to a child, gender unspecified.  If no gender-neutral singular/familiar form exists but a gender-neutral plural/formal form exists, use that instead.
Maze.instructions3_m2: instructions - 'steps' refers to instructions in a computer program; 'path' refers to the path through a maze. See previous description for tense.
Maze.instructions4_m2: instructions - 'steps' refers to instructions in a computer program; 'path' refers to the path through a maze. See previous description for tense.
Maze.instructions5_m2: instructions - 'path' refers to a path through a maze, and 'block' refers to a child's building block.
Maze.instructions6_m2: instructions - 'path' refers to a path through a maze, and 'block' refers to a child's building block.
Maze.instructions7_m2: instructions - 'path' refers to a path through a maze, and 'block' refers to a child's building block.
Maze.instructions8_m2: instructions - 'path' refers to a path through a maze, and 'block' refers to a child's building block.
Maze.instructions9_m2: instructions - 'path' refers to a path through a maze, and 'block' refers to a child's building block.
Maze.instructions10_m2: instructions - 'path' refers to a path through a maze, and 'block' refers to a child's building block.
Maze.instructions11_m2: instructions - the goal is reaching the end point in a maze; 'block' refers to a child's building block.
Maze.instructions12_m2: instructions - the goal is reaching the end point in a maze; 'block' refers to a child's building block.
Maze.instructions13_m2: instructions - 'turn left' refers to rotating in place a quarter circle counter-clockwise. An example of an 'if' block is: 'if there is a path to the left, turn left'.
Maze.instructions14_m2: instructions - 'turn left' refers to rotating in place a quarter circle counter-clockwise. An example of an 'if' block is: 'if there is a path to the left, turn left'.
Maze.instructions15_m2: instructions - an example of an 'if' block is: 'if there is a path to the left, turn left'.
Maze.instructions16_m2: instructions - an example of an 'if' block is: 'if there is a path to the left, turn left'.
Maze.instructions17_m2: instructions - 'block' refers to a child's building block.
Maze.instructions18_m2: instructions - an example of an 'if-else' block is: 'if there is a path to the left, turn left, else or otherwise turn right'.
Maze.codeTooltip: tooltip (pop-up help) for button; pressing the button causes a program in the JavaScript computer language to be displayed, based on the program created by the user.
Maze.linkTooltip: tooltip (pop-up help) for button; pressing the button causes the user's program to be saved and for a URL to be provided for retrieving it.  The word 'blocks' is as in children's toy blocks.
Maze.runProgram: button label - Pressing the button runs the computer program the user has written.
Maze.resetProgram: button label - Pressing the button causes Pegman return to the start of the maze (but does not delete the user's program.)
Turtle.title: TODO
Turtle.turtle1: brief title - Specifies that this is Blockly's '''Turtle 1''' tutorial.
Turtle.turtle2: brief title - Specifies that this is Blockly's '''Turtle 2''' tutorial.
Turtle.turtle3: brief title - Specifies that this is Blockly's '''Turtle 3''' tutorial.
Turtle.tryAgain: button - Closes the dialog and stays on the current level
Turtle.continue: button - Closes the dialog and continues to the next level
Karel.moveForward: verb - imperative or infinitive for a person moving (walking) in the direction he/she is facing.
Karel.putDownBall: verb - imperative or infinitive for a person putting down a ball.
Karel.pickUpBall: verb - imperative or infinitive for a person picking up a ball.
Karel.while: condensed form of 'while something is true'
Karel.ballsPresent: Indicates the presence of at least one ball, as in 'he brought a ball, there are now balls present'
Karel.holesPresent: Indicates the lack of any balls, as in 'she took the last ball, there are now no balls present'
Karel.turnLeft: verb - imperative or infinitive for a person turning his head and body one quarter rotation counter-clockwise.  Prefer a translation that has text in common with the translation of 'turn right'.  See [[Translating:Blockly#Drop-Down_Menus]].
Karel.turnRight: verb - imperative or infinitive for a person turning his head and body one quarter rotation clockwise. Prefer a translation that has text in common with the translation of 'turn left'.  See [[Translating:Blockly#Drop-Down_Menus]].
Karel.doCode: verb - imperative or infinitive preceding one or more commands to a person.
Karel.elseCode: conjunction - 'otherwise', introducing commands to be performed if a previous condition was not true, as in 'if x>3, do this, else do that'.
Karel.pathAhead: condensed form of 'if there is a path ahead', as in: 'if path ahead, go forward'.
Karel.pathLeft: condensed form of 'if there is a path to the left', as in: 'if path to the left, turn left'.
Karel.pathRight: condensed form of 'if there is a path to the right', as in: 'if path to the right, turn right'.
Karel.noPathAhead: condensed form of 'if there is a no path ahead', as in: 'if no path ahead, go forward'.
Karel.noPathLeft: condensed form of 'if there is a no path to the left', as in: 'if no path to the left, turn left'.
Karel.noPathRight: condensed form of 'if there is a no path to the right', as in: 'if no path to the right, turn right'.
Karel.repeatUntilBlocked: verb - imperative or infinitive to repeat the following commands.  The phrase is followed by the symbol denoting the end of the maze.
Karel.repeatUntilFinish: verb - imperative or infinitive to repeat the following commands.  The phrase is followed by the symbol denoting the end of the maze.
Karel.repeatWhileCurrentNotClear: verb - imperative or infinitive to repeat the following commands.  The phrase is followed by the symbol denoting the end of the maze.
Karel.moveForwardTooltip: tooltip (pop-up help) - Pegman is the humanoid icon used in Google Maps. See picture at http://goo.gl/9I64i (http://maps.google.com/intl/en/help/maps/streetview/learn/pegman.html). The term 'space' refers to a single square within a maze.
Karel.q4wrong: tracking is suggesting to the user that they should follow each instruction and follow how that will affect the movement. A 'program' is a set of instructions that tell the computer what to do next.
Karel.q4right: Congratulating the user on correctly answering the question.
Karel.q5wrong: tracking is suggesting to the user that they should follow each instruction and follow how that will affect the movement. A 'program' is a set of instructions that tell the computer what to do next.
Karel.q5right: Congratulating the user on correctly answering the question.
Karel.q10wrong: tracking is suggesting to the user that they should follow each instruction and follow how that will affect the movement. A 'program' is a set of instructions that tell the computer what to do next.
Karel.q10right: Congratulating the user on correctly answering the question.
Karel.turnTooltip: tooltip (pop-up help) - Pegman is the humanoid icon used in Google Maps. See picture at http://goo.gl/9I64i (http://maps.google.com/intl/en/help/maps/streetview/learn/pegman.html). The term 'space' refers to a single square within a maze.
Karel.ifTooltip: tooltip (pop-up help) - 'path' refers to a path through a maze.
Karel.ifelseTooltip: tooltip (pop-up help) - 'path' refers to a path through a maze.
Karel.whileTooltip: tooltip (pop-up help) - Repeat the enclosed commands until the maze has been successfully completed (the end point reached).
Karel.capacity0: warning - No more blocks may be added until some are removed.  Do not alter the portions between pointy brackets (< and >), although you may move them within the phrase and replace 0 with one or more words.
Karel.capacity1: warning - Only one more block may be added.  Do not alter the portions between pointy brackets (< and >), although you may move them within the phrase and replace 1 with one or more words.
Karel.capacity2: warning - Only %1 more blocks may be used, where %1 is an integer greater than 1.  Do not alter the portions between pointy brackets (< and >), although you may move them within the phrase.
Karel.nextLevel: alert - This is displayed when the user solves the maze, inviting them to precede to the next level of difficulty.
Karel.finalLevel: alert - This is displayed when the user solves the most difficult level.
Karel.oneTopBlock: alert - This is displayed if a user attempts to run a program composed of multiple stacks of blocks, letting them know they need to create a single stack.
Karel.putdownTower: Place a tower on the ground
Karel.pickupTower: Place a tower up off the ground
Karel.maze: brief title - Specifies that this is Blockly's '''Maze''' tutorial.
